action_space.name: Build and Maintain the Therapeutic Relationship
action_space.goal: Establish trust, rapport, and collaboration as the foundation for effective therapy.
action_space.description: The therapist demonstrates warmth, empathy, accurate understanding, and transparency; elicits feedback regularly; collaborates on decisions; and flexibly adapts style to the patient's needs.

micro_actions.name: Demonstrate Empathy and Accurate Understanding
micro_actions.description: Show warmth, careful listening, and understanding through verbal statements, tone, and body language.

micro_actions.name: Elicit and Respond to Feedback
micro_actions.description: Regularly ask for verbal and written feedback about the session, understanding, and any points of difficulty; make adjustments based on feedback to strengthen the therapeutic alliance.

micro_actions.name: Share Conceptualization and Treatment Plan
micro_actions.description: Explain the cognitive model and specific case conceptualization to the patient, confirming it resonates and revising collaboratively as needed.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Decision-Making
micro_actions.description: Work with the patient to set agendas, select interventions, and plan homework, actively seeking their input and agreement.

micro_actions.name: Vary Therapist Style as Needed
micro_actions.description: Observe patient reactions and adapt interpersonal approach (e.g., tone, degree of formality, encouragement) to fit the patient's preferences and increase comfort.

action_space.name: Structure and Plan Therapy Sessions
action_space.goal: Maximize treatment efficiency, clarity, and patient understanding by using a consistent session structure and pre-session planning.
action_space.description: Sessions follow a standard structure (mood check, agenda setting, homework review, problem discussion, planning, summarizing, obtaining feedback) tailored by stage of therapy; the therapist prepares before sessions based on case conceptualization, past sessions, and patient goals.

micro_actions.name: Pre-Session Planning
micro_actions.description: Prior to session, review therapy notes, prior homework, treatment goals, and agenda items; formulate a session-specific goal based on case conceptualization and current stage of therapy.

micro_actions.name: Mood Check and Agenda Setting
micro_actions.description: Begin the session with a check-in on mood/symptoms and collaboratively set an agenda for the session based on current problems and therapy goals.

micro_actions.name: Homework Review and Bridging
micro_actions.description: Review completion and outcomes of homework from previous sessions; discuss relevance to current work and adjust plans as needed.

micro_actions.name: Agenda-Based Problem Discussion
micro_actions.description: Address problems on the agenda through cognitive and behavioral techniques in the context of the session.

micro_actions.name: Session Summaries and Note-Taking
micro_actions.description: Summarize sections and overall session content (therapist and/or patient led); ensure important takeaways and plans are written down for the patient to review.

micro_actions.name: Session Feedback and Planning for Next Session
micro_actions.description: Obtain feedback on session process, address any difficulties or misunderstandings, and collaboratively plan topics and homework for next session.

action_space.name: Identify and Respond to Dysfunctional Cognitions
action_space.goal: Help patients recognize and modify inaccurate or unhelpful thoughts and beliefs to achieve cognitive, behavioral, and emotional change.
action_space.description: Use guided discovery/Socratic questioning, behavioral experiments, and other cognitive techniques to identify and evaluate automatic thoughts, intermediate beliefs, and core beliefs tied to distress or dysfunction.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Ask targeted questions (e.g., 'What was going through your mind?') in moments of distress or problematic behavior to reveal specific automatic thoughts.

micro_actions.name: Evaluate Thoughts Using Socratic Questioning
micro_actions.description: Ask about evidence for and against the thought, alternative explanations, likely outcomes, and effects of belief to guide patients toward new perspectives.

micro_actions.name: Design and Implement Behavioral Experiments
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively create real-life tests—potentially both in-session and as homework—to test the validity of negative predictions or beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Modify Intermediate and Core Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Use deepening questions, role-plays, self-comparisons, and acting 'as if' to help patients recognize, question, and experiment with more adaptive beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Address and Integrate Emotions
micro_actions.description: Support the direct processing of affect and help patients tolerate negative emotions while working on cognitive change.

action_space.name: Facilitate Cognitive and Behavioral Change Between Sessions (Homework)
action_space.goal: Promote and generalize skills and changes outside of sessions through individualized, collaboratively planned between-session activities.
action_space.description: Assign, record, and review homework that enables patients to practice new skills, apply cognitive restructuring, problem-solving, and behavioral experiments in real life; adapt difficulty level and expectations to avoid patient overwhelm.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Homework Assignment
micro_actions.description: Work jointly with the patient to define clear, specific, and agreed-upon homework tasks that are tailored to the patient's current needs and abilities.

micro_actions.name: Record Homework in Writing
micro_actions.description: Ensure assignments and key learning points are written down (by patient or therapist) so they can be reviewed between sessions.

micro_actions.name: Review and Troubleshoot Homework Adherence
micro_actions.description: In each session, review the previous homework; if incomplete, explore barriers, adjust expectations, and problem-solve collaboratively.

micro_actions.name: Adjust Difficulty and Scope
micro_actions.description: Assess likelihood of completion and, if needed, scale back, make optional, or break into more manageable steps to avoid overwhelm, especially with depressed or anxious patients.

action_space.name: Emphasize and Build on the Positive
action_space.goal: Counteract pervasive negative bias and foster resilience by helping patients notice and credit positive experiences and strengths.
action_space.description: Direct patient attention toward positive events, strengths, and successes; actively solicit and reinforce positive data that contradicts negative views.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Recent Positive Events and Actions
micro_actions.description: At each session, ask about positive things that have happened or helpful things the patient has done since the last meeting.

micro_actions.name: Highlight and Discuss Evidence Contradicting Negative Thoughts
micro_actions.description: When discussing problems, ask for or point out positive data undermining negative beliefs and discuss what this evidence means about the patient.

micro_actions.name: Reinforce Strengths and Coping Successes
micro_actions.description: Notice and call attention to instances where the patient has coped well, solved problems, or shown positive qualities.

micro_actions.name: Set Pleasure/Achievement-Focused Homework
micro_actions.description: Assign activities specifically designed to generate pleasure, a sense of accomplishment, or engagement with strengths.

action_space.name: Practice Behavioral Activation and Scheduling
action_space.goal: Increase engagement in rewarding and functional behaviors to counteract inactivity and negative mood, especially in depression.
action_space.description: Systematically schedule balanced activities that offer pleasure or mastery, monitor mood/pleasure levels, and address barriers to activation; use graded tasks and activity charts.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Schedule Daily Activities
micro_actions.description: Work with the patient to create a realistic daily schedule, including self-care, productive and pleasurable activities, and rest.

micro_actions.name: Use Activity/Mood Charts
micro_actions.description: Have patients record planned and completed activities along with corresponding ratings of mood, mastery, or pleasure; review for patterns and reinforce activation.

micro_actions.name: Identify and Address Interfering Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Elicit and collaboratively respond to negative predictions or beliefs (e.g., 'It won't help') that impede activity.

micro_actions.name: Use Graded Task Assignments
micro_actions.description: Break down larger or overwhelming tasks into manageable steps to increase success and build momentum.

action_space.name: Problem-Solving and Skills Training
action_space.goal: Equip patients with problem-solving abilities and practical skills to handle daily challenges, reduce distress, and improve functioning.
action_space.description: Teach and rehearse structured problem-solving steps; provide direct instruction or resources in deficient skill areas; help patients apply their skills in real-life contexts.

micro_actions.name: Structured Problem Solving
micro_actions.description: Identify and define the problem; brainstorm possible solutions; evaluate and select the best option; help the patient plan and implement the solution; evaluate its effectiveness.

micro_actions.name: Skills Training as Needed
micro_actions.description: Provide or refer for skills instruction (e.g., social skills, job interviewing, budgeting) and/or use self-help resources as appropriate.

micro_actions.name: Test and Extend Problem-Solving Skills
micro_actions.description: Help patients recognize and work through beliefs that impede problem solving or prevent application of existing skills.

action_space.name: Tailor Treatment and Maintain Flexibility
action_space.goal: Fit interventions, session focus, and pacing to the individual patient’s diagnosis, preferences, stage of therapy, learning characteristics, and current needs.
action_space.description: Continuously adapt plans and session focus, choose intervention level (automatic thoughts, beliefs, problem-solving, etc.), and be ready to shift agenda to optimize engagement and progress.

micro_actions.name: Assess and Plan by Stage of Therapy
micro_actions.description: Base choice of interventions and session plans on the current phase of therapy (e.g., early socialization, middle/skills development, termination/relapse prevention).

micro_actions.name: Prioritize Problems and Agenda Items
micro_actions.description: Focus on solvable, pressing problems first; sometimes defer complex or distressing issues until the patient is ready.

micro_actions.name: Shift Focus as Needed During Session
micro_actions.description: If an intervention is not effective or is causing distress, be ready to change topic, approach, or address underlying beliefs or alliance issues.

micro_actions.name: Customize Interventions for Individual Differences
micro_actions.description: Select interventions, pacing, and strategies that take into account the patient’s developmental stage, culture, motivation, and therapeutic alliance.

Conversation_states.Description: Current emotional state of the patient, tracked via subjective report and/or objective scales (e.g., Beck Depression Inventory). Used for mood checks at every session.
Conversation_states.Values: 0–10 scale or mild/moderate/severe; or standardized inventory total score.

Conversation_states.Description: Objective scores from scales such as Beck Depression Inventory, Beck Anxiety Inventory, Hopelessness Scale. Tracked at each session for progress and risk assessment.
List of problems/topics collaboratively set at the start of the session, including patient-identified concerns and therapist-proposed items.
Specific therapeutic objectives for the current session, set collaboratively and may vary by stage of therapy.
Quality of collaboration, rapport, and trust between therapist and patient, as evidenced by engagement and direct/indirect feedback.
Session-specific negative automatic thoughts (and associated emotions) identified as targets for evaluation/restructuring.
Conversation_states.Values: Free list or structured text; degree of belief (0–100%)

Conversation_states.Description: Strength of patient's endorsement of dysfunctional and alternative beliefs (core, intermediate), typically tracked as percent belief.
Degree to which homework tasks (cognitive and behavioral) are attempted/completed; patient's homework engagement.

Conversation_states.Variable Name: Session Summary and Key Points Retention
Conversation_states.Description: What patient remembers and records from the session's major conclusions, new strategies, and insights; assessed via summary or notes.
Patient's evaluation of the session, positive response, any concerns, or suggestions for change, used to monitor engagement and alliance.
Conversation_states.Values: Free text; options for 'Yes/No' bothered, suggestions

Conversation_states.Description: Current phase (early, middle, late/termination, relapse prevention) to guide session format, agenda, and technique adjustment.
Current active problems being tracked for resolution over sessions (e.g., studying, social withdrawal, assertiveness). Distinct from agenda as it persists across sessions.
Current assessment of acute risk factors (e.g., suicidal ideation, hopelessness) requiring potential emergency intervention.
Conversation_states.Values: 0–1: 0 = no risk, 1 = high risk; may be checklist item

Conversation_states.Variable Name: Notes on Core/Intermediate Beliefs & Case Conceptualization
Conversation_states.Description: Session notes relevant to evolving cognitive conceptualization and targets for belief modification, including new data and hypothesis updates.

knowledge_graph.description: Individual receiving Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT) for psychological disorders or problems.
Clinical identification of the patient's psychiatric disorders or psychological problems, forming the basis for conceptualization and treatment planning.
Fundamental, rigid, and overgeneralized self-related belief that influences perception, behavior, and emotions (e.g., incompetence, unlovability, worthlessness).
Assumptions, attitudes, or rules that mediate between core beliefs and automatic thoughts; more amenable to modification than core beliefs.
Situation-specific, rapid thoughts or images that spontaneously arise, influencing the patient's emotions and behavior.
Feelings such as sadness, anxiety, relief, and others, which may be triggered by automatic thoughts and beliefs.
Actions taken by the patient in response to cognitions and emotions, which may reinforce or maintain problems.
Environmental, internal, or external events or physiological triggers that give rise to automatic thoughts and emotional reactions.
Behavioral patterns or actions (e.g., overworking, avoidance, seeking help) developed to manage painful beliefs or emotions.
Cognitive map/framework developed by therapist to understand the patient's current and historical difficulties, beliefs, and coping strategies.
The collaborative relationship between patient and therapist, marked by trust, empathy, and teamwork, essential for effective CBT.
Real-life difficulty or distressing issue presented by the patient, requiring therapeutic intervention and problem solving.
A desired outcome or change, collaboratively set by patient and therapist to guide therapy (e.g., symptom relief, behavioral activation).
Structured meeting between therapist and patient, including agenda setting, cognitive and behavioral interventions, and feedback.
Self-help activities or assignments for the patient to complete between sessions to reinforce learning and facilitate change.
